questions.text: A 64-year-old woman comes to the physician because of several episodes of dizziness during the last month. The episodes last between 30–40 seconds and during the episodes, she feels as though she is spinning. Episodes usually occur immediately after lying down or suddenly sitting up from a reclined position. They also sometimes happen when she suddenly turns her head to look at something. She has no nausea. Last month, she had an upper respiratory tract infection that resolved spontaneously. She has hypertension treated with hydrochlorothiazide. Otoscopic examination shows no abnormalities. There is no lateralization when a vibrating 512 Hz tuning fork is placed in the middle of the forehead. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Patients with benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV) experience sudden, brief attacks of vertigo that usually last for less than a minute. These symptoms are caused by a dysfunction of the semicircular canal. Patients typically have no cochlear symptoms, such as hearing loss or tinnitus. This patient reports common triggers to these episodes, including lying down or reclining, and quickly turning her head. The Dix-Hallpike test is used to quickly diagnose BPPV and the Epley maneuver is used to treat BPPV. In refractory cases, patients can undergo surgical obliteration of the affected semicircular canal.

B) INCORRECT:

Persistent postural-perceptual dizziness (PPPD) typically worsens with movement, but the episodes are characterized by nonrotational dizziness (feeling faint, lightheaded, or unsteady) over a period of at least 3 months. This patient presents with true vertigo, which manifests as dizziness with a rotational component. Also, PPPD is often associated with anxiety or depression disorder, which this patient lacks.

C) INCORRECT:

Unlike this patient's episodes, symptomatic episodes of Meniere disease last from minutes to hours and are not triggered by position. In addition, typical features of Meniere disease include tinnitus and hearing loss, which this patient lacks.

D) INCORRECT:

Patients with cerebral ischemia in the vertebrobasilar region might present with dizziness. Although this patient has risk factors for a stroke, such as age and hypertension, symptoms of vertebrobasilar cerebral ischemia usually last longer than seconds, are not typically triggered by movement, and are often accompanied by other neurological deficits.

E) INCORRECT:

Acoustic neuromas can lead to an insidious onset of dizziness, but true spinning vertigo is uncommon, because of the slow-growing nature of the tumor (the CNS can usually compensate for gradual peripheral vestibular input loss). Also, her episodes are recurrent, and brief, rather than the chronic, gradual time course of acoustic neuromas. Other typical features of acoustic neuromas, such as unilateral hearing loss and tinnitus, are missing.
Image Description:

Acoustic neuromas are benign tumors that arise from Schwann cells and primarily originate within the vestibular portion of cranial nerve VIII. The tumor originates within the internal acoustic canal with variable extension into the cerebellopontine angle. Early symptoms occur due to pressure on the cochlear nerve (unilateral sensorineural hearing loss, tinnitus) and vestibular nerve (dizziness, unsteady gait, disequilibrium). If the tumor further expands into the cerebellopontine angle, further symptoms arise due to compression of CN V (paresthesia, hypoesthesia, unilateral facial pain), CN VII (unilateral facial weakness), and the cerebellum (ataxia).

F) INCORRECT:

Vestibular neuritis presents with an acute onset of vertigo and is sometimes associated with a history of preceding upper respiratory tract infection, as seen in this patient. The vertigo is typically accompanied by nausea, vomiting, and gait instability, which this patient lacks. Also, her symptoms occur in paroxysmal, positionally-elicited episodes that are too brief to be consistent with a diagnosis of vestibular neuritis, in which episodes usually last for 1–2 days.
questions.hint: The Epley maneuver can correct this condition.

questions.text: A 47-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of recurrent episodes of nausea and feeling like the room is spinning. Each episode lasts less than a minute and usually occurs when she gets out of bed in the morning or suddenly turns her head. She has not vomited and does not have headaches. She is asymptomatic between episodes. Which of the following findings most closely correlates with this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Intention tremor is a sign of cerebellar dysfunction that can result from a variety of neurological conditions. While some patients with intention tremor experience dizziness, this is due to disequilibrium secondary to cerebellar dysfunction rather than vestibular dysfunction. Dizziness due to a balance disorder is triggered by walking instead of head rotation, as seen in this patient.

B) CORRECT:

Vertigo and nausea are common symptoms of dysfunctions of the vestibular system, which often also present with pronounced nystagmus. This patient's episodic vertigo triggered by specific types of head movement suggests benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV), which is confirmed by observing nystagmus during a provoked maneuver such as the Dix Hallpike test.

Patients with a positive Dix Hallpike test for right-sided BPPV (with the head rotated to the right) will have rotational nystagmus with a counterclockwise rapid phase. Clockwise rapid phase nystagmus on rotation to the left is positive for left-sided BPPV.

C) INCORRECT:

A positive Romberg test is indicative of dysfunction of the dorsal columns, which can result from conditions such as longstanding uncontrolled diabetes mellitus or syphilis. Dorsal column dysfunction leads to sensory ataxia, which may manifest with vertigo. However, vertigo due to a sensory ataxia is triggered by movement of the extremities instead of head rotation as the symptoms in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Binocular diplopia, commonly known as double vision, is a sign of dysfunction of the extraocular muscles. While visual impairment can induce vertigo, it is not triggered by head rotation as in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

An abnormal Rinne test is a sign of conductive hearing loss, which can be caused by a variety of conditions, including cerumen impaction, otosclerosis, and otitis media. Although these conditions can cause dizziness, this patient's pattern of episodic vertigo triggered by specific types of head movement indicates a different cause for her symptoms.

F) INCORRECT:

Orthostatic hypotension is an episodic phenomenon that causes dizziness or faintness upon standing and may indicate cardiac or neurologic disease if it becomes recurrent. Although orthostatic hypotension is episodic, it does not present with vertigo and nausea as experienced by this patient. Furthermore, while orthostatic hypotension has positional triggers such as standing up, turning of the head does not trigger symptoms.

G) INCORRECT:

Expressive aphasia, also known as Broca aphasia, is a sign of dysfunction of the frontal lobe at the inferior frontal gyrus. Brain lesions can cause central vertigo, but this is usually due to lesions of the brain stem or cerebellum, not the frontal lobe. This patient's vertigo is episodic rather than chronic, as would be expected in a patient with lesions of the CNS.
questions.hint: This patient presents with vertigo and nausea, which are common symptoms of a vestibular disorder.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of intermittent episodes of nausea, vomiting, and a sensation that the room is spinning. The episodes last less than a minute and first started about 1 hour ago when she bent forward to tie her shoelaces. She reports no hearing loss or tinnitus. She has hypertension and dyslipidemia. Current medications include ramipril, amlodipine, and pravastatin. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 31 years and does not drink alcohol or use illicit drugs. Her father died of a stroke at 63 years of age. Her temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 97/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 142/82 mm Hg. Neurological examination shows horizontal nystagmus. Coordination testing is normal. Covering and uncovering of the eyes shows no gaze deviation. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Bedside provocation maneuvers (e.g., Dix-Hallpike maneuver, supine head roll test) are the best diagnostic tools for patients with BPPV. BPPV results from dislodged or abnormally adherent otoliths, leading to semicircular canal dysfunction. During the test, a set of specific sequential head positioning maneuvers are used to provoke symptoms. The presence of positional vertigo and nystagmus during the maneuvers indicates a positive test and confirms the diagnosis. Although BPPV resolves spontaneously in about half of all patients, canalith repositioning maneuvers (e.g., Epley maneuver) can also be performed in order to mobilize the otoliths out of the involved semicircular canals.
Image Description:

A testing procedure used in patients with episodic triggered vertigo to evaluate for benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV).

Starting in an upright seated position, the patient's head is rapidly rotated 45 degrees towards one side. Maintaining this degree of rotation, the patient is then quickly reclined and their head extended slightly below the end of the examination table (∼ 20 degrees). While holding this position, the examiner observes for 20–30 seconds for nystagmus and inquires regarding vertigo symptoms. The procedure is then repeated with the head rotated in the opposite direction. The test is positive (confirming BPPV) if the maneuver triggers nystagmus and/or vertigo during the observation period.

The Dix-Hallpike test with head rotation to the right tests the right posterior semicircular canal and the left anterior semicircular canal (and vice versa).
Illustrated here are the movements of the otoconia during the maneuver (black dots and arrows) and the upbeat nystagmus with an ipsiversive torsional component (i.e., the eye beats toward the forehead and the upper pole of the eye beats toward the affected ear), which represents a typical finding in posterior semicircular canal BPPV (present in approx. 95% of all patients with). In posterior canal BPPV, a positive result should only occur when the affected ear is turned towards the floor (unless BPPV is bilateral).

In anterior canal BPPV (rare), the nystagmus is downbeat instead (while maintaining the ipsiversive torsional component), and lateralization is less reliable (even in unilateral BPPV, testing either side may elicit nystagmus).

B) INCORRECT:

Audiometry is a useful diagnostic tool for patients with Meniere disease or acoustic neuroma, both of which can manifest with horizontal nystagmus, nausea, and vomiting. However, symptomatic episodes of Meniere disease usually last from minutes to hours and are not triggered by positioning while symptoms of acoustic neuroma typically have an insidious onset and a chronic course; this patient's brief and recurrent episodes of vertigo suggest a different diagnosis. In addition, both Meniere disease and acoustic neuroma typically manifest with hearing loss and tinnitus, neither of which are seen here.

C) INCORRECT:

Ultrasound of the carotids is a useful diagnostic method for carotid artery stenosis (CAS), which, in severe cases, can manifest with vertigo. This patient has several risk factors for atherosclerosis (history of hypertension, dyslipidemia, smoking), which increases her risk of developing CAS. However, she has no other features of carotid stenosis, such as carotid bruit, amaurosis fugax, or focal neurologic signs. In addition, the episodic nature of her symptoms and their correlation with position change indicates BPPV.

D) INCORRECT:

An MRI of the brain can be used to rule out intracranial causes of vertigo (e.g., acoustic neuroma, cerebellar infarction), which can manifest with dizziness and horizontal nystagmus. However, a marked spinning sensation is uncommon in patients with central vertigo. In addition, central vertigo is characterized by constant, rather than episodic symptoms, and is usually accompanied by other findings of intracranial lesions (e.g., focal neurologic deficits), which are absent in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

A caloric test can be used to differentiate between peripheral and central nystagmus in patients with vertigo. However, this patient's clinical presentation (short recurrent episodes of nausea, vomiting, and vertigo upon changing position) and physical examination findings (horizontal nystagmus, negative skew test) suggest BPPV, for which caloric testing is not typically indicated. In addition, this test is not commonly used for evaluating vertigo because of the associated symptoms (e.g., nausea, vomiting, ear discomfort) that most patients experience during the procedure.

F) INCORRECT:

Upright tilt table test is used to diagnose orthostatic syncope, which is characterized by prodromal vertigo and nausea with rapid loss of consciousness upon standing from a seated or prone position. Hypovolemia (e.g., due to hemorrhage, diuretic use), autonomic dysfunction (e.g., diabetic autonomic neuropathy), or a history of vasodilators use (e.g., alpha-blockers) are all risk factors for developing orthostatic syncope. Even though this patient presents with episodes of vertigo and nausea that are triggered by movement, none of them are followed by rapid loss of consciousness. In addition, she lacks any of the risk factors mentioned above, making orthostatic syncope unlikely.
questions.hint: This patient presents with horizontal nystagmus and short (< 1 minute) episodes of vertigo triggered by position change. These findings, in addition to a negative test of skew, indicate benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV).

questions.text:
A 45-year-old woman reports a 3-week history of vertigo that developed acutely. Recurrent vertigo is usually prompted by rapid head movement, typically toward the right, most often when she rolls over in bed with her right ear down. She is not vertiginous when she remains still. She reports no hearing loss, ataxia, difficulty swallowing, or double vision.
Her vital signs and general physical examination are normal. During neurologic examination, she has no vertigo at rest. When provoked by head movement, the patient's nystagmus is worse as she looks to the left and is not direction-changing. On walking, she lists to the right. When positioned with her head down to the right, there is a 30-second latency before the onset of severe vertigo; rotary up-beating nystagmus fatigues after approximately one minute.
Which one of the following conditions is the most likely cause of this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The combination of positional vertigo, normal hearing, and a positive Dix-Hallpike maneuver demonstrating rotary and/or up-beating nystagmus with latency and fatigability is most consistent with a diagnosis of benign paroxysmal positional vertigo.

Key learning point: The findings of positional vertigo, normal hearing, and a positive Dix-Hallpike maneuver demonstrating rotary and/or up-beating nystagmus with latency and fatigability are most consistent with a diagnosis of benign paroxysmal positional vertigo.

B) INCORRECT:

Acoustic schwannoma manifests as hearing loss and constant vertigo.

C) INCORRECT:

Ménière disease is characterized by the classic triad of hearing loss, tinnitus, and vertigo.

D) INCORRECT:

Brainstem stroke occasionally causes vertigo but is also characterized by cranial nerve findings such as diplopia, dysarthria, facial sensory loss, and difficulty swallowing. In addition, the nystagmus seen in central causes of vertigo (e.g., stroke) is often direction-changing.

E) INCORRECT:

Labyrinthitis is a less likely diagnosis, given that it is typically associated with hearing loss and occurs after a viral syndrome. Also, a purely positional component is more common in patients with benign paroxysmal positional vertigo.

questions.text:
A 50-year-old man reports sudden onset of a spinning sensation, nausea, vomiting, and unsteady gait shortly after hitting his head during a fall from a chair. He does not report ear pain, fever, or deafness.
His neurological motor, sensory, and coordination examinations are normal, except that after a rapid positional change, he experiences rotatory nystagmus that lasts less than a minute and recreates his symptoms.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV) can be caused by head trauma; vertigo and nystagmus are brief and prompted by movement. A thorough history is crucial because imaging is usually uninformative and formal vestibular testing is less available. A bedside Dix-Hallpike test is easy to conduct. BPPV that involves the posterior canal, which is the most common type, manifests with a prominent rotatory (torsional) nystagmus with a minor vertical (up-beating) component.

Key learning point: The most likely diagnosis in a patient with head trauma followed by nausea, vomiting, positional vertigo, and prominent rotatory nystagmus is benign paroxysmal positional vertigo.

B) INCORRECT:

Cerebellopontine contusion might produce incoordination of the limbs or gait, eye-movement abnormalities, or diminished level of consciousness, but it is not typically associated with episodic dizziness.

C) INCORRECT:

A temporal bone fracture might have no neurological consequences and is not specifically associated with dizziness.

D) INCORRECT:

Vestibular neuritis is position-independent, can be accompanied by ear pain and tinnitus, is usually monophasic, and lasts from hours to days.

E) INCORRECT:

Traumatic dislocation of the stapes produces hearing loss but not specifically with dizziness.

questions.text:
A 49-year-old woman presents with a one-day history of acute episodes of dizziness. She reports nausea without vomiting and feels generally weak but has no focal muscle weakness. She notes that the dizzy spells last about 15 seconds and always seem to be provoked by a change in her head position, including turning to her side in bed or gazing upward. The episodes are intense but resolve on their own, and she can prevent them by avoiding the head movements that trigger the spells.
On examination, the patient has a normal mental status with intact speech. Cranial-nerve, motor, and sensory examinations are unremarkable.
Observing the patient for nystagmus after which one of the following maneuvers is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?

choices.text: Placing the head in extension and rotating it 45 degrees while the patient is sitting — and then having the patient lie down quickly on her back with her head held in extension
With the patient recumbent, rotating the head to the affected side and then having the patient sit up
Moving the head from left lateral flexion to right lateral flexion and back to left lateral flexion
Bringing the patient from a supine to an upright sitting posture, while maintaining 45-degree rotation of the head
With the patient lying on her side, asking her to flex and extend at the neck

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV) is a common disorder that manifests as brief (10- to 20-second) episodes of intense vertigo provoked by certain changes in head position or gaze. There are no focal neurological deficits on examination.

The diagnosis is established with the help of the Dix-Hallpike maneuver. With the patient sitting upright, the head is rotated approximately 45 degrees to the patient’s right. The patient is then helped to lie down quickly on their back with their head held in approximately 20 degrees of extension. This is usually done with the patient’s head hanging off the examination table, and their eyes are observed.

The test is considered positive for BPPV when there is a 2- to 10-second period of latency before the onset of rotational nystagmus, which would be upbeat and torsional, with the top poles of the eyes beating toward the lower (right) ear. When the patient sits back up, the nystagmus will often reverse direction in cases of BPPV involving the posterior semicircular canal.

Key learning point: A diagnosis of benign paroxysmal positional vertigo can be established definitively using the Dix-Hallpike maneuver, which involves observing for nystagmus after placing the head in extension and rotating it 45 degrees.

B) INCORRECT:

In the Dix-Hallpike maneuver, neck rotation is performed when the patient is sitting up, not when the patient is recumbent.

C) INCORRECT:

Lateral neck flexion is not part of the Dix-Hallpike maneuver. Instead, the maneuver involves neck extension and rotation.

D) INCORRECT:

The Dix-Hallpike maneuver does not involve bringing the patient from a supine to an upright sitting posture. Instead, the maneuver involves bringing the patient from a sitting position to a supine one.

E) INCORRECT:

Lying on the side is not part of the Dix-Hallpike maneuver.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old man reports dizziness for the past 2 weeks. Several times a day, he experiences a severe sensation of spinning that is triggered by head movements, such as when he turns over in bed or looks upward. The sensation — which lasts about 15 seconds, is associated with transient nausea, and resolves spontaneously — is not accompanied by hearing changes, tinnitus, headache, fever, congestion, or other neurologic symptoms.
The clinician maneuvers the patient rapidly from a seated to a supine position while his supported head is turned to the side and then extended below the level of the table. Two seconds after the maneuver is started with the patient’s head turned to the right, the patient experiences severe vertigo with mixed torsional and vertical nystagmus.
What is the first-line treatment for this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Vestibular rehabilitation therapy can be useful for patients with ongoing vertigo or balance problems, but it is not a first-line treatment for benign paroxysmal positional vertigo.

B) INCORRECT:

Medications are generally ineffective in treating benign paroxysmal positional vertigo.

C) INCORRECT:

Medications are generally ineffective in treating benign paroxysmal positional vertigo.

D) INCORRECT:

Medications are generally ineffective in treating benign paroxysmal positional vertigo.

E) CORRECT:

Benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV) is characterized by brief episodes of vertigo provoked by a change in head position. It is caused by free-floating particulate matter (canaliths) in the endolymph of the semicircular canal. In patients with posterior canal BPPV (the most common subtype of BPPV), a Dix-Hallpike maneuver triggers vertigo and, typically, mixed torsional and upbeat nystagmus, with the upper pole of the eye beating toward the dependent ear and the upbeat nystagmus beating toward the forehead. The recommended treatment for posterior canal BPPV is the Epley maneuver, which helps reposition the canaliths into the vestibule of the semicircular canal where they can be resorbed.

In this maneuver, the patient is moved from a seated to a supine position with the head rotated 45 degrees toward the right and the neck slightly extended, followed 30 seconds later by slow rotation of the head until the left ear is facing down, followed 30 seconds later by further rotation of the head and body to the left. Then the patient is returned to a seated position.

Key learning point: The first-line treatment for benign paroxysmal positional vertigo is the Epley maneuver.

questions.text:
A 22-year-old healthy man reports that a few days ago when he woke up, he turned over in bed to the left, felt the room starting to spin, and became nauseated. The episode resolved in 20 to 30 seconds, but the patient has experienced a recurrence whenever he looks up or turns his head abruptly to the left. He bumped his head on a cabinet a few days before the first episode but otherwise has no history of trauma or recent illness. He denies fevers, hearing changes, ear pain, or drainage. Head and neck examination is normal.
Which one of the following features would you expect to find on further examination of this patient when you perform the Dix-Hallpike maneuver with his left ear down?

choices.text: Pure vertical nystagmus that persists after the maneuver is over
Horizontal saccades toward the right that last as long as the head is down
Direction-changing nystagmus, initially to the left and then to the right after 30 seconds
Upbeat-torsional nystagmus diagonally toward the left ear that lasts less than one minute
No nystagmus until the patient sits up

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

In a patient with benign paroxysmal positional vertigo, the Dix-Hallpike maneuver reveals these characteristic findings when the head is tilted down to the affected side: upbeat-torsional nystagmus that lasts less than a minute.

B) INCORRECT:

In a patient with benign paroxysmal positional vertigo, the Dix-Hallpike maneuver reveals these characteristic findings when the head is tilted down to the affected side: upbeat-torsional nystagmus that lasts less than a minute.

C) INCORRECT:

In a patient with benign paroxysmal positional vertigo, the Dix-Hallpike maneuver reveals these characteristic findings when the head is tilted down to the affected side: upbeat-torsional nystagmus that lasts less than a minute.

D) CORRECT:

Benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV), which is characterized by room-spinning vertigo that lasts from seconds to one minute, is induced by certain head movements. Physical examination reveals characteristic eye movements and symptoms provoked by manipulating the posterior semicircular canal.

The Dix-Hallpike maneuver induces symptoms by placing the patient in the plane of the posterior canal to cause movement of abnormally placed otoconia. The patient is initially seated, with their head turned 45 degrees, and then they are laid down, with their head hanging over the end of the table. In patients with BPPV, upbeat-torsional nystagmus beats quickly, with the top poles of the eyes beating diagonally toward the affected side when the head is tilted down to that side; when the patient sits up, the nystagmus reverses direction.

The Epley maneuver is used to treat BPPV, once diagnosed, by moving the posterior canal through its full rotation to reposition the abnormally placed otoconia. It is successful in about 80% of patients.

Key learning point: In a patient with benign paroxysmal positional vertigo, the Dix-Hallpike maneuver reveals these characteristic findings when the head is tilted down to the affected side: upbeat-torsional nystagmus that lasts less than a minute.

E) INCORRECT:

In a patient with benign paroxysmal positional vertigo, the Dix-Hallpike maneuver reveals these characteristic findings when the head is tilted down to the affected side: upbeat-torsional nystagmus that lasts less than a minute.

questions.text:
A 68-year-old woman with type 2 diabetes and hypertension reports episodes of dizziness for the past 2 to 3 weeks. The episodes occur whenever she moves her head “a certain way” and are characterized by nausea and the sensation that the room is moving around her. The episodes resolve in less than a minute but still interfere with her daily activities. She had similar episodes several years ago that resolved spontaneously after 6 to 8 weeks. She notes that her hearing has gradually worsened in both ears during the past 5 to 10 years, but she has no other neurologic symptoms.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Vestibular schwannoma very often manifests with vestibular symptoms, but the symptom is usually mild unsteadiness, rather than the short-duration, acute-onset, room-spinning vertigo of BPPV. Unilateral sensorineural hearing loss is common.

B) INCORRECT:

Vestibular neuritis is characterized by acute episodes of vertigo that last hours to days and are disabling.

C) INCORRECT:

Vestibular migraine can be associated with vertigo of varying lengths, but the episodes are usually longer than those of BPPV. In addition, the diagnosis of vestibular migraine requires another migraine-associated symptom, such as headache or aura.

D) INCORRECT:

Meniere disease is associated with tinnitus and hearing loss, but patients experience a sudden drop in hearing with severe episodes of vertigo, rather than slowly progressive hearing loss.

E) CORRECT:

Benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV) is characterized by episodes of vertigo that occur suddenly in relation to specific head movements and resolve in less than one minute. Patients may experience nausea and diaphoresis associated with the acute episodes but generally have no neurologic complaints other than the vertigo. In older patients, gradual age-related hearing loss is not unexpected and is likely unrelated to the BPPV.

Key learning point: The most likely diagnosis in an older patient with periodic, self-limited episodes of vertigo that last less than one minute is benign paroxysmal positional vertigo.

questions.text: A 47-year-old woman comes to the office because of a 3-month history of recurrent episodes of nausea and feeling like the room is spinning. Each episode lasts less than a minute and usually occurs when she gets out of bed in the morning or suddenly turns her head. She has not vomited and does not have headaches. She is asymptomatic between episodes. Which of the following findings most closely correlates with this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Intention tremor is a sign of cerebellar dysfunction that can result from a variety of neurological conditions. Dizziness due to a balance disorder is triggered by walking instead of head rotation, as seen in this patient.

B) CORRECT:

Vertigo and nausea are common symptoms of dysfunctions of the vestibular system, which often also present with pronounced nystagmus. This patient's episodic vertigo triggered by specific types of head movement suggests benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV), which is confirmed by observing nystagmus during a provoked maneuver such as the Dix Hallpike test.

Patients with a positive Dix Hallpike test for right-sided BPPV (with the head rotated to the right) will have rotational nystagmus with a counterclockwise rapid phase. Clockwise rapid phase nystagmus on rotation to the left is positive for left-sided BPPV.

C) INCORRECT:

An abnormal Rinne test is a sign of conductive hearing loss, which can be caused by a variety of conditions, including cerumen impaction, otosclerosis, and otitis media. Although these conditions can cause dizziness, this patient's pattern of episodic vertigo triggered by specific types of head movement indicates a different cause for her symptoms.

D) INCORRECT:

Orthostatic hypotension is an episodic phenomenon that causes dizziness or faintness upon standing and may indicate cardiac or neurologic disease if it becomes recurrent. Although orthostatic hypotension is episodic, it does not present with vertigo and nausea as experienced by this patient. Furthermore, while orthostatic hypotension has positional triggers such as standing up, turning of the head does not trigger symptoms.

Expressive aphasia, also known as Broca aphasia, is a sign of dysfunction of the frontal lobe at the inferior frontal gyrus. questions.text: A 64-year-old woman comes to the office because of several episodes of dizziness during the last month. The episodes last between 30–40 seconds and during the episodes, she feels as though she is spinning. Episodes usually occur immediately after lying down or suddenly sitting up from a reclined position. There is no lateralization when a vibrating tuning fork is placed in the middle of the forehead. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Patients with benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV) experience sudden, brief attacks of vertigo that usually last for less than a minute. These symptoms are caused by a dysfunction of the semicircular canal. Patients typically have no cochlear symptoms, such as hearing loss or tinnitus. This patient reports common triggers to these episodes, including lying down or reclining, and quickly turning her head. The Dix-Hallpike test is used to quickly diagnose BPPV and the Epley maneuver is used to treat BPPV. In refractory cases, patients can undergo surgical obliteration of the affected semicircular canal.

Key learning point: Benign paroxysmal positional vertigo presents as brief, recurrent episodes of vertigo triggered by changes in head position, without hearing loss or tinnitus.

B) INCORRECT:

Unlike this patient's episodes, symptomatic episodes of Meniere disease last from minutes to hours and are not triggered by position. In addition, typical features of Meniere disease include tinnitus and hearing loss, which this patient lacks.

C) INCORRECT:

Patients with cerebral ischemia in the vertebrobasilar region might present with dizziness. However, symptoms of vertebrobasilar cerebral ischemia usually last longer than seconds, are not typically triggered by movement, and are often accompanied by other neurological deficits.

D) INCORRECT:

Acoustic neuromas can lead to an insidious onset of dizziness, but true spinning vertigo is uncommon, because of the slow-growing nature of the tumor (the CNS can usually compensate for gradual peripheral vestibular input loss). Also, her episodes are recurrent, and brief, rather than the chronic, gradual time course of acoustic neuromas. Other typical features of acoustic neuromas, such as unilateral hearing loss and tinnitus, are missing.

E) INCORRECT:

Vestibular neuritis presents with an acute onset of vertigo, which is typically accompanied by nausea, vomiting, and gait instability. Also, her symptoms occur in paroxysmal, positionally-elicited episodes that are too brief to be consistent with a diagnosis of vestibular neuritis, in which episodes usually last for 1–2 days.
questions.hint: The Epley maneuver can correct this condition.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man reports dizziness for the past 2 weeks. Several times a day, he experiences a severe sensation of spinning that is triggered by head movements. Episodes last about 15 seconds, are associated with nausea, and resolve spontaneously. They are not accompanied by other symptoms. The patient is positioned quickly from a seated to a supine position while his head is turned to the side and then extended below the level of the table. Two seconds after the maneuver, the patient experiences severe vertigo with nystagmus. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Vestibular rehabilitation therapy can be useful for patients with ongoing vertigo or balance problems, but it is not a first-line treatment for BPPV.

B) INCORRECT:

Medications are generally ineffective in treating BPPV.

C) INCORRECT:

Medications are generally ineffective in treating BPPV.

D) INCORRECT:

Medications are generally ineffective in treating BPPV.

E) CORRECT:

Benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV) is characterized by brief episodes of vertigo provoked by a change in head position. BPPV is caused by free-floating particulate matter (canaliths) in the endolymph of the semicircular canal. The recommended treatment for posterior canal BPPV is the Epley maneuver, which helps reposition the canaliths into the vestibule of the semicircular canal where they can be resorbed. In this maneuver, the patient is moved from a seated to a supine position with the head rotated 45 degrees toward the right and the neck slightly extended, followed 30 seconds later by slow rotation of the head until the left ear is facing down, followed 30 seconds later by further rotation of the head and body to the left. Then the patient is returned to a seated position.

Key learning point: The first-line treatment for benign paroxysmal positional vertigo is the Epley maneuver.
questions.hint: The Dix-Hallpike test (i.e., rotating the head to the side and positioning the patient quickly from a seated to a supine position with the head below the level of the table) is used to diagnose benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV). The test is positive when positional vertigo and nystagmus are triggered during the maneuver.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of intermittent episodes of nausea, vomiting, and a sensation that the room is spinning. The episodes last less than a minute and first started about 1 hour ago when she bent forward to tie her shoelaces. She has hypertension and dyslipidemia. Neurological examination shows horizontal nystagmus. Coordination testing is normal. Covering and uncovering of the eyes shows no gaze deviation. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Bedside provocation maneuvers (e.g., Dix-Hallpike maneuver, supine head roll test) are the best diagnostic tools for patients with BPPV. BPPV results from dislodged or abnormally adherent otoliths, leading to semicircular canal dysfunction. During the test, a set of specific sequential head positioning maneuvers are used to provoke symptoms. The presence of positional vertigo and nystagmus during the maneuvers indicates a positive test and confirms the diagnosis. Although BPPV resolves spontaneously in about half of all patients, canalith repositioning maneuvers (e.g., Epley maneuver) can also be performed in order to mobilize the otoliths out of the involved semicircular canals.
Image Description:

A testing procedure used in patients with episodic triggered vertigo to evaluate for benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV).

Starting in an upright seated position, the patient's head is rapidly rotated 45 degrees towards one side. Maintaining this degree of rotation, the patient is then quickly reclined and their head extended slightly below the end of the examination table (∼ 20 degrees). While holding this position, the examiner observes for 20–30 seconds for nystagmus and inquires regarding vertigo symptoms. The procedure is then repeated with the head rotated in the opposite direction. The test is positive (confirming BPPV) if the maneuver triggers nystagmus and/or vertigo during the observation period.

The Dix-Hallpike test with head rotation to the right tests the right posterior semicircular canal and the left anterior semicircular canal (and vice versa).
Illustrated here are the movements of the otoconia during the maneuver (black dots and arrows) and the upbeat nystagmus with an ipsiversive torsional component (i.e., the eye beats toward the forehead and the upper pole of the eye beats toward the affected ear), which represents a typical finding in posterior semicircular canal BPPV (present in approx. 95% of all patients with). In posterior canal BPPV, a positive result should only occur when the affected ear is turned towards the floor (unless BPPV is bilateral).

In anterior canal BPPV (rare), the nystagmus is downbeat instead (while maintaining the ipsiversive torsional component), and lateralization is less reliable (even in unilateral BPPV, testing either side may elicit nystagmus).

B) INCORRECT:

Ultrasound of the carotids is a useful diagnostic method for carotid artery stenosis (CAS), which, in severe cases, can manifest with vertigo. This patient has several risk factors for atherosclerosis (history of hypertension and dyslipidemia), which increases her risk of developing CAS. However, she has no other features of carotid stenosis, such as carotid bruit, amaurosis fugax, or focal neurologic signs. In addition, the episodic nature of her symptoms and their correlation with position change indicates BPPV.

C) INCORRECT:

An MRI of the brain can be used to rule out intracranial causes of vertigo (e.g., acoustic neuroma, cerebellar infarction), which can manifest with dizziness and horizontal nystagmus. However, a marked spinning sensation is uncommon in patients with central vertigo. In addition, central vertigo is characterized by constant, rather than episodic symptoms, and is usually accompanied by other findings of intracranial lesions (e.g., focal neurologic deficits), which are absent in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

A caloric test can be used to differentiate between peripheral and central nystagmus in patients with vertigo. However, this patient's clinical presentation (short recurrent episodes of nausea, vomiting, and vertigo upon changing position) and physical examination findings (horizontal nystagmus, negative skew test) suggest BPPV, for which caloric testing is not typically indicated. In addition, this test is not commonly used for evaluating vertigo because of the associated symptoms (e.g., nausea, vomiting, ear discomfort) that most patients experience during the procedure.

E) INCORRECT:

Upright tilt table test is used to diagnose orthostatic syncope, which is characterized by prodromal vertigo and nausea with rapid loss of consciousness upon standing from a seated or prone position. Hypovolemia (e.g., due to hemorrhage, diuretic use), autonomic dysfunction (e.g., diabetic autonomic neuropathy), or a history of vasodilators use (e.g., alpha-blockers) are all risk factors for developing orthostatic syncope. Even though this patient presents with episodes of vertigo and nausea that are triggered by movement, none of them are followed by rapid loss of consciousness. In addition, she lacks any of the risk factors mentioned above, making orthostatic syncope unlikely.
questions.hint: This patient presents with horizontal nystagmus and short (< 1 minute) episodes of vertigo triggered by position change. These findings, in addition to a negative test of skew, indicate benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV).

questions.text: A 47-year-old woman comes to your clinic with a 3-month history of recurrent episodes of nausea and a sensation that the room is spinning. Each episode lasts less than a minute and typically occurs when she gets out of bed in the morning or suddenly turns her head. She has not vomited and does not have headaches. She is asymptomatic between episodes. Which one of the following findings most closely correlates with her symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Vertigo and nausea are common symptoms of dysfunctions of the vestibular system, which often also present with pronounced nystagmus. This patient's episodic vertigo triggered by specific types of head movement suggests benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV), which is confirmed by observing nystagmus during a provoked maneuver such as the Dix Hallpike test.

Patients with a positive Dix Hallpike test for right-sided BPPV (with the head rotated to the right) will have rotational nystagmus with a counterclockwise rapid phase. Clockwise rapid phase nystagmus on rotation to the left is positive for left-sided BPPV.

Key learning point: Benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV) is characterized by brief episodes of vertigo triggered by head movement and is confirmed by positional nystagmus during maneuvers like the Dix-Hallpike test.

B) INCORRECT:

Orthostatic hypotension is an episodic phenomenon that causes dizziness or faintness upon standing and may indicate cardiac or neurologic disease if it becomes recurrent. Although orthostatic hypotension is episodic, it does not present with vertigo and nausea as experienced by this patient. Furthermore, while orthostatic hypotension has positional triggers such as standing up, turning of the head does not trigger symptoms.

C) INCORRECT:

An abnormal Rinne test is a sign of conductive hearing loss, which can be caused by a variety of conditions, including cerumen impaction, otosclerosis, and otitis media. Although these conditions can cause dizziness, this patient's pattern of episodic vertigo triggered by specific types of head movement indicates a different cause for her symptoms.

D) INCORRECT:

Expressive aphasia, also known as Broca aphasia, is a sign of dysfunction of the frontal lobe at the inferior frontal gyrus. Brain lesions can cause central vertigo, but this is usually due to lesions of the brain stem or cerebellum, not the frontal lobe. This patient's vertigo is episodic rather than chronic, as would be expected in a patient with lesions of the CNS.

E) INCORRECT:

Intention tremor is a sign of cerebellar dysfunction that can result from a variety of neurological conditions. While some patients with intention tremor experience dizziness, this is due to disequilibrium secondary to cerebellar dysfunction rather than vestibular dysfunction. Dizziness due to a balance disorder is triggered by walking instead of head rotation, as seen in this patient.
questions.hint: This patient presents with vertigo and nausea, which are common symptoms of a vestibular disorder.

questions.text: A 64-year-old woman comes to your clinic because she has experienced several episodes of dizziness over the past month. Each episode lasts 30–40 seconds and is described as a sensation of spinning. The episodes typically occur immediately after she lies down or suddenly sits up from a reclined position. When a vibrating tuning fork is placed in the middle of her forehead, there is no lateralization. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Vestibular neuritis presents with an acute onset of vertigo, which is typically accompanied by nausea, vomiting, and gait instability. Also, her symptoms occur in paroxysmal, positionally-elicited episodes that are too brief to be consistent with a diagnosis of vestibular neuritis, in which episodes usually last for 1–2 days.

B) CORRECT:

Patients with benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV) experience sudden, brief attacks of vertigo that usually last for less than a minute. These symptoms are caused by a dysfunction of the semicircular canal. Patients typically have no cochlear symptoms, such as hearing loss or tinnitus. This patient reports common triggers to these episodes, including lying down or reclining, and quickly turning her head. The Dix-Hallpike test is used to quickly diagnose BPPV and the Epley maneuver is used to treat BPPV. In refractory cases, patients can undergo surgical obliteration of the affected semicircular canal.

Key learning point: Benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV) causes brief episodes of vertigo triggered by head movements, without hearing loss or tinnitus, due to dysfunction of the semicircular canals.

C) INCORRECT:

Patients with cerebral ischemia in the vertebrobasilar region might present with dizziness. However, symptoms of vertebrobasilar cerebral ischemia usually last longer than seconds, are not typically triggered by movement, and are often accompanied by other neurological deficits.

D) INCORRECT:

Acoustic neuromas can lead to an insidious onset of dizziness, but true spinning vertigo is uncommon, because of the slow-growing nature of the tumor (the CNS can usually compensate for gradual peripheral vestibular input loss). Also, her episodes are recurrent, and brief, rather than the chronic, gradual time course of acoustic neuromas. Other typical features of acoustic neuromas, such as unilateral hearing loss and tinnitus, are missing.

E) INCORRECT:

Unlike this patient's episodes, symptomatic episodes of Meniere disease last from minutes to hours and are not triggered by position. In addition, typical features of Meniere disease include tinnitus and hearing loss, which this patient lacks.
questions.hint: The Epley maneuver can correct this condition.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man comes to your clinic with a 2-week history of dizziness. He describes several daily episodes of severe spinning sensation triggered by head movements. Each episode lasts about 15 seconds, is associated with nausea, and resolves on its own. He does not report any other symptoms. During examination, you quickly move him from a seated to a supine position with his head turned to the side and extended below the level of the table. Two seconds after this maneuver, he experiences severe vertigo with nystagmus. Which one of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Medications are generally ineffective in treating BPPV.

B) CORRECT:

Benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV) is characterized by brief episodes of vertigo provoked by a change in head position. BPPV is caused by free-floating particulate matter (canaliths) in the endolymph of the semicircular canal. The recommended treatment for posterior canal BPPV is the Epley maneuver, which helps reposition the canaliths into the vestibule of the semicircular canal where they can be resorbed. In this maneuver, the patient is moved from a seated to a supine position with the head rotated 45 degrees toward the right and the neck slightly extended, followed 30 seconds later by slow rotation of the head until the left ear is facing down, followed 30 seconds later by further rotation of the head and body to the left. Then the patient is returned to a seated position.

Key learning point: The first-line treatment for benign paroxysmal positional vertigo is the Epley maneuver.

C) INCORRECT:

Vestibular rehabilitation therapy can be useful for patients with ongoing vertigo or balance problems, but it is not a first-line treatment for BPPV.

D) INCORRECT:

Medications are generally ineffective in treating BPPV.

E) INCORRECT:

Medications are generally ineffective in treating BPPV.
questions.hint: The Dix-Hallpike test (i.e., rotating the head to the side and positioning the patient quickly from a seated to a supine position with the head below the level of the table) is used to diagnose benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV). The test is positive when positional vertigo and nystagmus are triggered during the maneuver.

questions.text: You are seeing a 55-year-old woman who is brought to the emergency department with intermittent episodes of nausea, vomiting, and a sensation that the room is spinning. The episodes last less than a minute and began about 1 hour ago when she bent forward to tie her shoelaces. Her medical history includes hypertension and dyslipidemia. Neurological examination reveals horizontal nystagmus. Coordination testing is normal. Cover-uncover testing shows no gaze deviation. Which one of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Ultrasound of the carotids is a useful diagnostic method for carotid artery stenosis (CAS), which, in severe cases, can manifest with vertigo. This patient has several risk factors for atherosclerosis (history of hypertension and dyslipidemia), which increases her risk of developing CAS. However, she has no other features of carotid stenosis, such as carotid bruit, amaurosis fugax, or focal neurologic signs. In addition, the episodic nature of her symptoms and their correlation with position change indicates BPPV.

B) INCORRECT:

An MRI of the brain can be used to rule out intracranial causes of vertigo (e.g., acoustic neuroma, cerebellar infarction), which can manifest with dizziness and horizontal nystagmus. However, a marked spinning sensation is uncommon in patients with central vertigo. In addition, central vertigo is characterized by constant, rather than episodic symptoms, and is usually accompanied by other findings of intracranial lesions (e.g., focal neurologic deficits), which are absent in this patient.

C) CORRECT:

Bedside provocation maneuvers (e.g., Dix-Hallpike maneuver, supine head roll test) are the best diagnostic tools for patients with BPPV. BPPV results from dislodged or abnormally adherent otoliths, leading to semicircular canal dysfunction. During the test, a set of specific sequential head positioning maneuvers are used to provoke symptoms. The presence of positional vertigo and nystagmus during the maneuvers indicates a positive test and confirms the diagnosis. Although BPPV resolves spontaneously in about half of all patients, canalith repositioning maneuvers (e.g., Epley maneuver) can also be performed in order to mobilize the otoliths out of the involved semicircular canals.

Key learning point: Benign paroxysmal positional vertigo is best diagnosed with bedside head positioning maneuvers, such as the Dix-Hallpike test, which provoke vertigo and nystagmus.
Image Description:

A testing procedure used in patients with episodic triggered vertigo to evaluate for benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV).

Starting in an upright seated position, the patient's head is rapidly rotated 45 degrees towards one side. Maintaining this degree of rotation, the patient is then quickly reclined and their head extended slightly below the end of the examination table (∼ 20 degrees). While holding this position, the examiner observes for 20–30 seconds for nystagmus and inquires regarding vertigo symptoms. The procedure is then repeated with the head rotated in the opposite direction. The test is positive (confirming BPPV) if the maneuver triggers nystagmus and/or vertigo during the observation period.

The Dix-Hallpike test with head rotation to the right tests the right posterior semicircular canal and the left anterior semicircular canal (and vice versa).
Illustrated here are the movements of the otoconia during the maneuver (black dots and arrows) and the upbeat nystagmus with an ipsiversive torsional component (i.e., the eye beats toward the forehead and the upper pole of the eye beats toward the affected ear), which represents a typical finding in posterior semicircular canal BPPV (present in approx. 95% of all patients with). In posterior canal BPPV, a positive result should only occur when the affected ear is turned towards the floor (unless BPPV is bilateral).

In anterior canal BPPV (rare), the nystagmus is downbeat instead (while maintaining the ipsiversive torsional component), and lateralization is less reliable (even in unilateral BPPV, testing either side may elicit nystagmus).

D) INCORRECT:

A caloric test can be used to differentiate between peripheral and central nystagmus in patients with vertigo. However, this patient's clinical presentation (short recurrent episodes of nausea, vomiting, and vertigo upon changing position) and physical examination findings (horizontal nystagmus, negative skew test) suggest BPPV, for which caloric testing is not typically indicated. In addition, this test is not commonly used for evaluating vertigo because of the associated symptoms (e.g., nausea, vomiting, ear discomfort) that most patients experience during the procedure.

E) INCORRECT:

Upright tilt table test is used to diagnose orthostatic syncope, which is characterized by prodromal vertigo and nausea with rapid loss of consciousness upon standing from a seated or prone position. Hypovolemia (e.g., due to hemorrhage, diuretic use), autonomic dysfunction (e.g., diabetic autonomic neuropathy), or a history of vasodilators use (e.g., alpha-blockers) are all risk factors for developing orthostatic syncope. Even though this patient presents with episodes of vertigo and nausea that are triggered by movement, none of them are followed by rapid loss of consciousness. In addition, she lacks any of the risk factors mentioned above, making orthostatic syncope unlikely.
questions.hint: This patient presents with horizontal nystagmus and short (< 1 minute) episodes of vertigo triggered by position change. These findings, in addition to a negative test of skew, indicate benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV).

questions.text: A 67-year-old woman presents with episodic vertigo for 2 days, triggered by rolling over in bed and getting up from lying down. Episodes last 20–30 seconds and resolve spontaneously. She denies hearing loss, headache, or neurological symptoms. The Dix-Hallpike maneuver with the right ear dependent produces minimal vertigo symptoms but no clearly observable nystagmus. The left-sided Dix-Hallpike maneuver is negative. What is the most appropriate next step?

choices.text: Perform Epley maneuver on the right side

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct -- Approximately 25% of patients with BPPV may show little or no nystagmus on provoking maneuvers despite having classic symptoms. The Epley maneuver can be performed as a therapeutic trial even when nystagmus is minimal or absent. This patient's symptoms during the right-sided maneuver suggest right posterior canal involvement.

B) INCORRECT:

The supine head roll test is indicated when the Dix-Hallpike maneuver is negative or shows atypical findings to assess for lateral canal benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV). This patient had symptoms with the right-sided Dix-Hallpike maneuver, which makes posterior canal BPPV more likely.

C) INCORRECT:

Neuroimaging is reserved for atypical presentations, persistent vertigo, or when central causes are suspected. This patient has classic positional vertigo symptoms and a suggestive clinical examination.

D) INCORRECT:

While benign paroxysmal positional vertigo may resolve spontaneously, canalith repositioning maneuvers are the preferred first-line treatment with an 80–90% success rate. This patient's symptoms and positive provocative testing warrant treatment.

E) INCORRECT:

Vestibular suppressants are reserved for intractable vertigo or patients who decline repositioning maneuvers. They are not routinely indicated for benign paroxysmal positional vertigo and may inhibit central compensation.
